metadata.title: COPAM: High performance compact heat exchangers in pure copper by combining gyroid lattice structure design with laser based additive manufacturing and novel post-processing routes.
metadata.author: N/A

content.full_text:
Plan Overview
Plan Overview
A Data Management Plan created using DMPonline.be
Title: 
Title: 
COPAM: High performance compact heat exchangers in pure copper by combining gyroid lattice structure design with laser based
additive manufacturing and novel post-processing routes.
Creator:
Creator:
Brecht Van Hooreweder
Affiliation: 
Affiliation: 
KU Leuven (KUL)
Funder: 
Funder: 
KU Leuven (KUL)
Template: 
Template: 
KU Leuven BOF-IOF
Project abstract:
Project abstract:
Copper is the most conductive metal available besides silver. Hence it is ideally suited for heat extraction and thermal
cooling applications, especially when complex optimized geometrical shapes with high surface to volume ratios can
be produced by for instance the use of Additive Manufacturing (AM). This ambitious research project aims at reducing
the mass and increasing the specific thermal performance of pure copper heat exchangers significantly. This will be
achieved by researching novel gyroid lattice structure designs, beyond state-of-the-art laser based additive
manufacturing processes, unique post-processing strategies and in-depth understanding of the mechanical and
thermal behaviour of the structures. The intended outcome is a validated proof-of-concept of a multi-functional
compact and lightweight copper heat exchanger, combining high specific structural and thermal performance in one
integrated component. This project will serve as a catalyst for the collaboration between KU Leuven and UC Louvain
on Additive Manufacturing while the resulting demonstrator will be used to attract industrial attentions and to define
follow-up projects at higher TRL with industrial stakeholders in Belgium and beyond.

This ambitious research project aims at reducing the mass and increasing the specific thermal performance of pure copper heat exchangers significantly. This project will serve as a catalyst for the collaboration between KU Leuven and UC Louvain on Additive Manufacturing while the resulting demonstrator will be used to attract industrial attentions and to define follow-up projects at higher TRL with industrial stakeholders in Belgium and beyond.
